title: Gagosian Highlights Zao Wou-Ki’s Friendship with I.M. Pei
text:
'Juin-Octobre 1985' by Chinese painter Zao Wou-Ki during a media preview for the piece at the Sothebys auction house showroom in Hong Kong on September 26, 2018, ahead of its auction on September 30.

Text size

The Chinese-American architect I.M. Pei and Chinese-French artist Zao Wou-Ki met in Paris in 1951, after Pei saw one of Zao’s paintings at the Pierre Loeb gallery and asked the gallerist for an introduction to the artist.

“They immediately became friends,” says Jean-Olivier Després, director of Gagosian gallery in Paris. “They remained friends the rest of their lives.”

The friendship, and artistic partnership, between Pei, the Pritzker prize-winning architect who died in May at age 102, and Zao, who died at age 93 in 2013, is being celebrated at Gagosian in New York at an exhibition of Zao’s ink works that opened this week and runs through Oct. 26.

Zao Wou Ki's 'Sans titre,' 2006, India ink on paper mounted on canvas 106 3/4 x 83 7/8 in © 2019 Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York / ProLitteris, Zurich Courtesy Gagosian

Zao, born in Beijing in 1920, is more known for his dynamic, oil-painted abstracts, full of color and light. Last October, Zao’s Juin-Octobre 1985, a mammoth triptych spanning more than 9-feet by 32-feet, realized HK$510.4 million (US$65.2 million) at Sotheby’s in Hong Kong.

At Pei’s behest, Zao created his first ink-on-paper works in a large format as a 1982 commission for the architect’s Fragrant Hill Hotel in Beijing, China. As ink-on-paper works, the pieces evoke Zao’s roots in the East, though expressed through the abstract and Modernist style Zao had been practicing in Europe.

“The language the artist conveys with these specific works is very musical, with an intense rhythm and Eastern aesthetic,” Després says.

While Pei influenced Zao by encouraging him to return to ink, the reverse is also true, as Zao traveled to Egypt with Pei “to explore the pyramids for the architect’s project at the Louvre in Paris,” Després says. “They exchanged ideas about art, culture, and its influence.”

The exhibition at Gagosian’s Madison Avenue gallery includes works that are privately owned, as well as works for sale, although the gallery doesn’t comment on prices.

The exhibited pieces include two small works on paper from 1979 and 1980, which are prototypes for the Fragrant Hill Hotel project. “There are also seven large works on paper mounted on canvas from the same series, all made from India ink,” Després says.

The series, representing the largest works Zao created in ink, was made in 2006 and was the “very last” series the artist completed, he says.
description: The New York gallery is featuring ink-on-paper works by the Chinese-French painter best known for his abstracts
